3: East City's Xujiu Street... Wang's Pawn Shop, this is the last store.
Changyu is standing in front of a building and sifting through his memories. Seeing that it is still the same building as before, he enters the premises.
In the pawnshop, a middle-aged man is sitting behind the counter, looking down at the panel in his hand. In his other, an old copper coin is being absentmindedly twirled.
Boss Wang? I saw that you're hiring, so...
Huh? But what's a kiddo like you doing here?
Age isn't a problem. I can do whatever it is you need.
Know your way around machines?
Boss Wang slowly raises his head and taps a coin on the table. His indifferent tone feels like a sharp knife to Changyu's ears.
I, um... No, I don't.
Then shoo.
You can't possibly think the KCC still has any use for elbow grease now, do you?
Oh... I see. You're from the old parts down south. No wonder.
Well then, be on your way. I don't have any use for a kid like you.
Boss Wang waves his hand at the door, motioning for Changyu to leave. Hearing this, Changyu takes a step forward instead.
It's not like that. Some things are best left to people.
Oh? And what's that? I'm all ears.
Like... Pawning... You know, sales!
Machines might replace the need for people in the service, manufacturing, or entertainment industries because they are good at imitating humans.
But the one they can't do is barter!
Each customer is different. You need intuition and honesty to understand their needs to make money.
Hmm, I see your point...
Then—
However—
Boss Wang drags out his rebuttal to interrupt Changyu's rambling.
A person's speech and behavior are telltale signs of their thoughts. You speak with confidence, but your eyes darted four times over the place—indicating that you've been nervous this whole time.
Machines only have to pick up on this to simulate human emotion and adjust their sales strategy accordingly. That's not specific to humans.
...But that type of machine doesn't exist.
Hmph, maybe you haven't heard...
Boss Wang remarks coldly. Just as he is about to continue speaking, Changyu suddenly steps forward and puts his hand on the copper coin resting on the table.
Think I don't know about the Fuxi Crew's research into human simulation?
Oh? Looks like you aren't as naive as I thought.
I heard it from some big shot a long time ago.
But a machine like that isn't something normal folks like us can afford.
So this kind of job is best left to us humans for the time being.
Ain't nothing wrong with replacing us with machines. But until then, do you really think someone in your condition can look after the shop all by yourself?
How'd you know about my condition?
Changyu lifts his hand off the coin and smiles.
Hehe, my bro Chen at our theater used to have this problem. I was a bit hesitant when I walked in at first. I didn't want to say anything without a closer look.
Sharp eh, kid?
I'll take that as a compliment.
Hmph.
Hearing this, Boss Wang scoffs and leaves the store.
You work 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. Six days a week. Salary is performance based.
So that means that I'm...
Hmph, you're starting tomorrow. Don't be late on your first day of work.
Alrighty!
Five thousand, here you are. Come again!
After seeing off the last customer, Changyu returns to the pawnshop and carefully seals the pawned item he just received.
Hey, kiddo. Clean up and get ready to call it a day.
Huh, why so early today?
It's not like I want to. I just received a notice from the Chiwen Crew. No business after 5 p.m.
How come?
It probably has to do with the news report released by the World Government. Some experiment failed, and there was some sort of repercussion.
You mean zero-point energy?
Yeah, that thing. But the only repercussion is our loss of business!
No wonder the customers are all so sour-looking recently.
Hmph, you can say that again.
By the way, I also saw the notice that the celebration was postponed—the one you mentioned earlier that your theater's playing at.
What? It was postponed?!
Can't help it. Hosting a celebration right now would be a slap in the face for the World Government.
Ugh... At least it's not cancelled. We'll just have to wait for this all to pass. Then everything will be back to normal.
We can only hope so. The sooner the curfew ends, the sooner we can open normally. I'm going to head out. Be sure to lock up once you're done cleaning.
Yeah, got it.
After Boss Wang leaves, Changyu returns to the counter. He turns on his data panel and begins to flip through the calendar.
It's delayed... But that's not necessarily a bad thing.
That gives me more time to prepare for the performance. Director, just you wait...
Boss Wang, what's going on today? I've seen Pulao soldiers patrolling the streets.
The whole city is under a curfew. The zero-point thingamajig failed and created some virus. Apparently, a machine will go haywire if it becomes infected.

Now the soldiers are recycling machines, androids, and even all the police bots in the city—the uh, Guardians and Tai'E, I think? Anyway, they're all gone. Heard they're roundin' them up and disposing them all at once.
No wonder the Glazed Arch Theater next door has been so deserted recently. I thought they were upgrading the androids in preparation for something big during the celebration.
Alright, enough chit-chat. Throw this out for me.

He throws Changyu a palm-sized robot from behind the counter. The electronic brain is hanging sideways, with indentations obviously caused by a blunt object. Several broken wires are also poking out of its casing.
Isn't this the robot you bought to wipe the cabinet? How did this happen?
The soldiers don't recycle these lil' gizmos. Hmph, but who's to say it won't get infected and wreck the shop?
Don't just stand there. Get this eyesore out of here!
Changyu picks up the broken pile of scrap metal and walks to the trash can in the alley around the corner.
...And he sees a trashcan filled to the brim with an assortment of mechanical parts—electronic terminals, carrier drones, and other household gadgets.
The tools that once brought many conveniences to mankind were now completely destroyed and randomly discarded in the dark recesses of trash cans, mixed with foods scraps and other garbage.
Pah... That's the way humans got their jobs back, huh?
Changyu shakes his head as he walks out of the alley. He sees several strange devices in the street erected by the Baxia Crew.
Hearing the news, Boss Wang pokes his head out from the doorframe of the pawnshop and looks down the street.
The KCC... is about to change.
Indeed...
'Indeed'? What does a kid like you know?
That's not what I meant...
Here, take this.
Having no intention of arguing with Changyu, Boss Wang interrupts him by throwing him a data card.
Huh? Didn't you already pay me this month?
A cheapskate like you is giving me a bonus?!
Who are you callin' a cheapskate? It's called running a well-managed business. You should take some notes.
Whatever you say boss. As long as you keep paying me.
Still playing the poverty card? Get out of here. I'm closing up shop.
Alright, alright. Quit pushing me. I was just on my way out.
Boss Wang pushes Changyu out as he speaks and impatiently motions him to hurry home.
After Changyu boards the shuttle back to the South City District, Boss Wang returns to the shop.
Pah, I've been crunching numbers my whole life. This might be my last bit of generosity.
With that, Boss Wang takes off the weathered plaque to the door of the shop and firmly closes the pawnshop door.
Up next, an emergency statement from the Kowloong Chamber of Commerce.
The Kowloong Chamber of Commerce is still under curfew. Please remain at home as much as possible and report any emergencies to the nearby Kowloong Crew immediately.
Large machinery throughout the city has been recycled. Do not panic. This situation must be handled rationally. Now, let's listen to Lord Danhao, the Bian Crew official to...
Changyu, where are you going?
Hehe, I'm just goin' out for a bit.
Didn't you hear the broadcast? Are you really going out with all that's happened?
I'm just one last step away from fixing all the props. Just wait a bit longer, Director.
How are you still thinking about the celebration at a time like this?
The celebration isn't what matters. I just want to get the Kowloong Theater up and running again.
Changyu!
Changyu quickly drags the props out of the theater and leaves the nagging director behind.
Almost there.
Up next, an emergency statement from the World Government on the Punishing Virus.
We face an unprecedented disaster in human history. The Science Council has launched a comprehensive investigation, and the Star of Life is actively seeking a cure.

Throughout the streets, the World Government's updates on the Punishing Virus is being broadcasted in real-time. The once prosperous KCC is now long gone. Only a few pedestrians are watching the broadcast on the street.
The broadcast echoes throughout Kowloong. Changyu quickly shuttles between the road with the props in hand.
Made it.
What! It's closed...
Changyu starts to grow flustered at the sight of the locked repair shop.
What should I do now? It was open yesterday.
Damn it! There aren't any shops nearby that can repair our old equipment.
Hey, punk. Today's our lucky day.
You guys again?
Who are you calling a punk?
Leave me alone. I'm not in the mood for this right now.
What are you sayin', tough guy?!
Don't you know? I've got a bone to pick with you. I'm going to make you suffer today.
Most of the police cyborgs have been disposed of, and the Pulao Crew are busy with the plaza and the East City District. Who can save you now?
Suddenly, the deafening sound of a broadcast plays in the distance, cutting through the air.
**** you. I don't need anyone's help to take care of you guys.
Don't you wanna fight? Bring it!
